description.narrative: # of strategies developed.

Authorities are supported to provide inclusive and multi-sectoral crisis management and response to COVID-19, in coordination with the UN Country Team and in direct collaboration with the World Health Organisation in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1. Indicator: Extent to which authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina manage to respond to the emergency needs related to COVID-19 disease outbreak in a timely and coordinated manner.

comment.narrative: 1.UNDP is supporting overall coordination of the crisis by supporting the Civil Protection and Rescue Coordination Body to coordinate actions and exchange information among relevant stakeholders, as well as deploy tools that help the whole-of-system data collection and management, as well as information sharing on the crisis to the public. UNDP is also conducting an extensive, in-depth analysis focusing on the COVID-19 response and challenges from the security point of view. The assessment provides an overview of the human security and policing sectors in country, national and regional challenges and vulnerabilities as well as general analysis of the security threats and proposals for prospective interventions in this field. The analysis have mapped several priorities and provided recommendations for policy and operational support to the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

description.narrative: The socio-economic impact of COVID-19 is addressed through a whole-of-society approach and rapid economic impact assessment available and launch of a real-time economic “pulse” meter platform;
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1. Number of measures developed based on the assessment findings and companies supported to recover from the COVID-19 crisis.

comment.narrative: 1. At least 3 assessments and/or tools produced or supported with recommendations which proivde basis to at least 5 projects in implementing Covid-19 recovery measures

1. 7 assessments/tools 8 projects On behalf of the UNCT and in direct cooperation with the World Health Organisation, UNDP provided support to the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina to ensure effective and multi-sectoral crisis coordination in the country. It included information management on the current situation and needs for the COVID-19 pandemic in the country, including response, recovery and prevention planning, as well as resource mobilization. Also, in May 2020 UNDP prepared an Economic Impact Assessment of COVID-19 in BiH, a survey that served to assess the extent of the immediate COVID-19 impact to businesses and industries in the country. The Economic Pulse of Bosnia and Herzegovina is an interactive platform for collecting data on the socio-economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including the state of the private sector and it was launched by UNDP as part of this project. In addition, serological tests were purchased for medical institutions in Bosnia and Herzegovina on their request for immediate assistance, due to the increasing number of registered cases.
1. At least 3 assessments and/or tools produced or supported with recommendations which proivde basis to at least 5 projects in implementing Covid-19 recovery measures

description.narrative:
Ind.1.1.1 - Existence d'un document de proposition de nouveau cadre reg et institutionnel Ind.1.1.2.a- Existence de plateforme de communication facilitant l’échange entre le SHOCROOM national, les directions du ministère de la santé et ceux au niveau régional Ind.1.1.2 b % de membres de la Direction de l’Hygiène du Milieu et de la Protection de l’Environnement au MInistère de la Santé formés en communication pour assurer une coordination avec le SHOCROOM et les directions régionales (Cible = 90% ; 40% de femmes) Ind.1.1.3 # Nombre de commissions régionales de gestion de crise appuyées et /ou renforcées (cible = 3) Ind.1.1.4 - # Nombre de municipalités appuyées et /ou renforcées (cible = 4) Ind.1.1.5 - # d'initiatives de la société civile pour la résilience sociale appuyées (cible = 10) Ind.1.1.5.b - # d"initiatives de la société civile dont les équipes et/ou les bénéficiaires sont des femmes (cible = 5)
Ind.2.1.1 # d'agents de la santé et de l'ONAS bénéficiant des équipements de protection de base (cible = 1000 agents dont 30% de femmes) Ind.2.1.2.a Existence d'une étude sur l'état des lieux du volume des déchets DAS dangereux C19 et des capacités des équipes (Cible = oui) Ind.2.1.2.b # d'étude d'impact COVID en termes de qualité de l'eau (usée et de surface) élaborée (cible =1) 2.1.2.c - # de personnels des intervenants de gestion des déchets liquides et solides formés en systèmes de gestion des DAS , politiques, évaluation des déchets, normes internationales et lignes directrices (cible = 100, 40% de femmes) Ind.2.1.3.a # nombre d'analyses de la qualité des eaux usées et de surface effectuées (cible = 20) Ind.2.1.3.b # de rapports des résultats de l'analyse pour les décideurs (cible = 2) Ind.2.1.3.c # Un suivi périodique de la qualité des eaux usées et de surface (cible = 1) Ind.2.1.4 # nombre de personnel recruté pour appuyer le laboratoire (cible = 1) Ind.2.1.5 # d'hôpitaux dotés d'équipements spécifiques de gestion DASRI pour répondre à C

comment.narrative:
Ind.1
▪ Une proposition de revue du cadre institutionnel et réglementaire de la gestion de risque de catastrophes et crise intégrant le retour d’expérience COVID19 ▪ Deux directions régionales de la santé ainsi que deux commissions régionales de gestion de catastrophes et crises et un comité local institutionnel des zones d’intervention du projet bénéficieront d’un appui en renforcement de capacité en coordination de la crise ; ▪ Dix associations bénéficieront de financements (grants) pour mettre en œuvre des initiatives qui visent à renforcer la résilience de la société face aux conséquences de la pandémie sur l’exacerbation des conflits communautaires et environnementaux et réduire son impact sur la cohésion sociale et la marginalisation des femmes et des catégories les plus vulnérables. ▪ Quatre municipalités bénéficieront d’un appui en renforcement de capacité en préparation à et coordination de la crise.
Ind.2. ▪ 4 initiatives incubées proposées par les jeunes femmes et hommes des localisations visées ▪ Une plateforme e-learning pour l’éducation à la santé et environnement est mise en place en partenariat avec l’Université Virtuelle de Tunis ▪ 200 professionnel.les de santé formé.es via la plateforme e-learning ▪ 10 000 citoyen.nes sensibilisé.es atteint.es à travers cette plateforme

Résultat 1 N/A
Résultat 2 : Liste et quantités d'équipements et matériels estimés et Cahier des charges finalisé 1 post doctorant recruté et mis à la disposition du laboratoire des maladies transmissibles et des substances biologiquement actives à travers son unité de virologie environnementale pour conduire les analyses de la qualité des eaux usées

Ind.1.a % d'initiatives d'OSC appuyées qui coordonnent avec les instances nationales, régionales et locales (cible = 70%) Ind.1.b Degré de coordination et coopération pour la conception des documents, plans stratégiques et plateforme (cible = 4 selon l'échelle suivante = 0-pas de coordination, 1-coordination organisée par un acteur externe, 2-coordination partielle (quelques acteurs ou sur une partie des activités, 3- coordination continue sur quelques activités ou coordination partielle sur toutes les activités, 4-coordination de tous les acteurs sur toutes les activités) Ind.1.1. a - % d'acteurs nationaux, régionaux et locaux accompagnés qui déclarent que leurs compétences en coordination sont améliorées (cible = 50%) Ind.1.1.b - % d'acteurs nationaux, régionaux et locaux accompagnés qui déclarent avoir amélioré leur coordination (cible = 50%) Données désagrégées par genre (Sexe, Age -35 +35) et territoires Ind.1.1.1 - Existence d'un document de proposition de nouveau cadre reg et institutionnel (Cible = oui) Ind.1.1.2.a- Existence de plateforme de communication facilitant l’échange entre le SHOCROOM national, les directions du ministère de la santé et ceux au niveau régional (Cible = oui) Ind.1.1.2 b % de membres de la Direction de l’Hygiène du Milieu et de la Protection de l’Environnement au MInistère de la Santé formés en communication pour assurer une coordination avec le SHOCROOM et les directions régionales (Cible = 90% ; 40% de femmes) Ind.1.1.3 # Nombre de commissions régionales de gestion de crise appuyées et /ou renforcées (cible = 3) Ind.1.1.4 - # Nombre de municipalités appuyées et /ou renforcées (cible = 4) Ind.1.1.5 - # d'initiatives de la société civile pour la résilience sociale appuyées (cible = 10) Ind.1.1.5.b - # d’initiatives de la société civile dont les équipes et/ou les bénéficiaires sont des femmes (cible = 5) Ind.2.a # d'institutions recevant un appui en mesure de proposer de nouvelles prestations liées au COVID-19 (cible = 3 - Ministères de la Santé et Ministère de l'Environnement Laboratoire des maladies transmissibles) Ind.2.1.a Existence d'un plan d'action pour la gestion DAS dangereux dus à COVID informé par les études et analyses produites dans le cadre du projet (cible = oui) Ind.2.1.b Degré d'évolution des capacités des équipes de gestion des déchets DAS dangereux sur le court et moyen termes (Cible = bon à très bon - échelle définie post étude d'identification) 2.1.2. Existence d'un plan d'action pour le suivi de la qualité des eaux usées et de surface et de solutions pour prévenir la contamination COVID - C19 (cible = oui) Ind.2.1.1 # d'agents de la santé et de l'ONAS bénéficiant des équipements de protection de base (cible = 1000 agents dont 30% de femmes) Ind.2.1.2.a Existence d'une étude sur l'état des lieux du volume des déchets DAS dangereux C19 et des capacités des équipes (Cible = oui) Ind.2.1.2.b # d'étude d'impact COVID en termes de qualité de l'eau (usée et de surface) élaborée (cible =1) 2.1.2.c - # de personnels des intervenants de gestion des déchets liquides et solides formés en systèmes de gestion des DAS , politiques, évaluation des déchets, normes internationales et lignes directrices (cible = 100, 40% de femmes) Ind.2.1.3.a # nombre d'analyses de la qualité des eaux usées et de surface effectuées (cible = 20) Ind.2.1.3.b # de rapports des résultats de l'analyse pour les décideurs (cible = 2) Ind.2.1.3.c # Un suivi périodique de la qualité des eaux usées et de surface (cible = 1) Ind.2.1.4 # nombre de personnel recruté pour appuyer le laboratoire (cible = 1) Ind.2.1.5 # d'hôpitaux dotés d'équipements spécifiques de gestion DASRI pour répondre à COVID pour une période d'un mois (cible = 6) Ind.2.2 - # Nombre et type d'initiatives innovantes et participatives pour l'atténuation de l'impact COVID-19 (cible = 2) Ind.2.2.1 # d'évaluation d'impact COVID19 sur l'environnement (cible = 1) Ind.2.2.2 # d'initiatives incubées proposées par les jeunes femmes et hommes des territoires ciblés (cible = 4) Ind 2.2.3.a Existence d'une plateforme e-learning pour l'éducation de la santé (cible = Oui) Ind 2.2.3.b nombre de professionnel de santé formés via la plateforme à distance (cible = 200, 50% de femmes) Ind 2.2.3.c Nombre de citoyennes touché.es par la plateforme (cible = 10 000) Ind.3.a Audience des communications sur le projet dans les médias Ind.3.b # et type de débats et événements autour des réalisations du projet
Ind.3.1 audience des communications dans les médias Ind.3.1.1.a # de supports et documents partagés et diffusés (cible = tout.e.s) Ind.3.1.1.b # de publications, articles publiés, .documentaire, témoignages... Pour le public (cible = 3) Ind.3.1.2. # de documents portants sur les meilleures pratiques du projet (cible = 1) Ind.3.2 - qualité de mise en œuvre selon les standards du PNUD telle que notée dans le module Qualité Assurance (cible = satisfaisante) Ind.3.2.1.a Existence d'une Unité de gestion du projet mis en place (cible = oui) Ind.3.2.1.b Degré de respect des processus qualité du PNUD (cible = 3)

capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: Indicator 1. Whether COVID response and recovery strategy development is supported Indicator 2. Whether resource mobilization and financing strategy in place and funds toward recovery available and utilized by 30 September 2020 Indicator 3. Whether COVID-19 socio-economic assessment tool by using BIG data is developed

comment.narrative: no covid situation, therefore no need to have a rapid response to build back.

Target 1. National strategy developed by 1 June 2020 Target 2. Resource mobilization and financing strategy in place and funds toward recovery available and utilized by 30 September 2020. Target 3. COVID-19 socio-economic assessment tool by using BIG data developed.

Results of target 1: • UNDP was the technical lead on the socio-economic recovery and assisted the Deputy Prime Minister’s (DPM) Office in developing a recovery strategy though an inclusive process. Based on consultations four strategic areas, social recovery, economic recovery, supportive governance and institutions, and environmental and climate resilience are identified as crucial for recovery within the coming 2 years to build forward better. The Socio-Economic Response Plan was developed by the country office to contribute to the Government’s action plan and its implementation plan for pandemic response.
Results of target 2: • Resource mobilization and financing strategy was integrated in implementation plan of the Government Integration plan approved in December, 2020. • The UNDP’s transformational learning journey, “What development means in a post normal Mongolia” is being developed.
Results of target 3: • With the National Statistics Office and Customs and Tax Information Center, the pilot estimation of the household consumption, inequality and other indicators by using VAT is being undertaken. By January, the report will be ready.

description.narrative: 1.1: Recruitment of national UNVs 1.2. Application of behavioral insights (BI) and tailored communication campaign in multi-languages (Arabic, English, Hindi, Urdu and others) 1.3. Support a mobile platform to support real-time identification of multidimensional needs arising from vulnerable communities, i.e. Jleeb Al-Shoyokh and Mahboula areas, as well as people with disabilities 1.4. Pilot a digital platform to trace (past movements) of COVID-19 patients with rights-based approach 1.5: Strengthening a hotline (support system) for supporting victims of domestic violence 2.1. Running Hackathons for New Business Prototypes (knowledge-based/innovation track and e-commerce track) 2.2. Identification of business mentors and mentorship programs drawn from the national as well as global pool of business leaders (start-ups)

comment.narrative: 1.1: Recruitment of national UNVs 1.2. Application of behavioral insights (BI) and tailored communication campaign in multi-languages (Arabic, English, Hindi, Urdu and others) = to be concluded in 1.3. Support a mobile platform to support real-time identification of multidimensional needs arising from vulnerable communities, i.e. Jleeb Al-Shoyokh and Mahboula areas, as well as people with disabilities 1.4. Pilot a digital platform to trace (past movements) of COVID-19 patients with rights-based approach 1.5: Strengthening a hotline (support system) for supporting victims of domestic violence 2.1. Running Hackathons for New Business Prototypes (knowledge-based/innovation track and e-commerce track) 2.2. Identification of business mentors and mentorship programs drawn from the national as well as global pool of business leaders (start-ups)

1.1: Recruitment of national UNVs 2.1. Two innovation challenges (Local Hackathon and Regional ideathon) were organise to solicit creative ideas to help overcoming covid-19 related challenges. 2.2. Identification of business mentors and mentorship programs drawn from the national as well as global pool of business leaders (start-ups).
Extra activities added at a later stage: - Volunteers manuals were developed and in the process to be printed and circulated widely in Kuwait, and Training Of Trainers For Volunteers And Volunteer Management has been delivered. - Rapid Response Catalogue were developed and printed and circulated widely in Kuwait. - Development of a policy paper, titled: “Polarized Reactions, Attitudes and Behaviors towards Covid-19: Behavioral Analysis”. - Socio-Economic Analysis on the effect of COVID-19: UNDP Kuwait is leading a socioeconomic assessment on the impact of COVID19 on the most vulnerable groups such as people with disabilities (PWD) and migrants. Collaborating with the Public Authority of The Disabled (PADA), UNDP Kuwait aims to provide a review and analysis on current social protection processes put in place for PWD. - SDG Accelerator lab for SMEs in Kuwait is under development, to be concluded in Q1 2021. - Development of Chatbot powered by Artificial Intelligence (AI) to improve the wellbeing of people during the crisis. Results from mental and physical health questionnaires will assist in the design of an interactive platform. The interactive WhatsApp platform is aimed at Kuwaiti citizens and residents towards accessing information related to their health on a real-time basis, to be concluded in Q1 2021.

Strengthening the capacity of national health systems to respond to COVID-19, including through procurement of critical medical equipment and enhancing the effectiveness of risk communication
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1.1 Improved Capacity of National Health System to conduct domestic testing of COVID19 Cases 1.2 Number of COVID19 Cases identified and contained through immediate testing and response services 1.3 Number of Multimedia Awareness Campaigns on COVID19 Preparedness and Response disseminated and distributed at the National scale 1.4 Number of people particularly the Vulnerable groups disaggregated by gender that are supported through Community Outreach and Engagement support initiatives.

comment.narrative: 1.1 Complete procurement and delivery of PCR Testing Equipment with relevant consumables and supplies 1.2 At least 500 COVID19 Tests administered and completed locally with timely avaiable results 1.3 At least 100 Multimedia Awareness Messages on COVID19 Preparedness and Response produced and nationally disseminated 1.4 At least 300 vulnerable families supported through COVDI19 Community Outreach support

1. Under the COVID-19 Response project, UNDP in partnership with UNICEF successfully procured a RT-qPCR machine and 2,000 test kits to enhance local testing capabilities. 2. Under the reprogrammed CERF funds, UNDP also procured 2,000 Cepheid test kits for Samoa's existing GenXpert machines (previously funded under GFATM projects). 3. In addition to that, UNDP worked through a number of civil society organizations and directly with small businesses who were heavily impacted by COVID to locally produce face masks in Samoa, Niue and Tokelau, and hand sanitizer in Samoa, for distribution to health care workers and vulnerable households.

description.narrative: Support to a inclusive and integrated COVID-19 response that leaves no one behind
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 2.1 Number for Zoom License successfully procured and activated to support Governments' Business Continuity plan 2.2 Number of PPEs that were locally produced in accordance with WHO Guidance and disseminated nationally 2.3 Number of people particularly the vulnerable groups disaggregated by gender and age supported with social protection support of food packages and hygiene kits 2.4 Number of Persons with disabilities disaggregated by gender and age supported with social protection support of food packages and hygience kits.

comment.narrative: 2.1 At least 50 Zoom licenses successfully procured and activated to support Governments' Business Continuity plan 2.2 At least 300 2 plies facemasks locally producted and distributed at national scale for infection prevention and control 2.3 At least 500 vulnerable families supported through social protection immediate support of food packages and hygiene kits 2.4 At least 300 persons' with disabilities supported through social protection immediate support of food packages and hygiene kits.

1. UNDP successfully procured 78 Zoom licenses to support the Governments' of Samoa, Niue and Tokelau business continuity. 2. In UNDP's partnership with the Samoa Victim Support Group on local production of face masks, 15 women survivors of DV/GBV were selected to contribute to the effort and sew cloth face masks from the confines of their homes given the COVID restrictions. This group of women alone have sewn over 1,500 masks, becoming the main income earners for their families during these trying times. The masks are also sold online via the Maua App, and have been purchased by private companies, private citizens, and Poutasi village (a COVID-19 quarantine site for those returning from NZ). Furthermore, a field visit to the project on 16 September revealed that SVSG's extensive sharing of posts promoting the UNDP face mask production on social media attracted the attention of a new hotel in Apia, which placed the order for sewing of all its tablecloths and napkins by the women survivors of violence. 3. Progress-on-track for distribution of hygiene packages, food voucher and cash power/electricity support to vulnerable families, in partnership with MWCSD. 4. UNDP in partnership with NOLA successfully distributed 450 hygiene packages as support to Persons with Disabilities in Samoa. 5. Progress-on-track for support to Koko Youth Farmers on plant care, soil and weather management training, in partnership with Chamber of Commerce, SPREP and Samoa MET.

description.narrative: COVID-19 SocEc Imp Ass & Recov_Supporting Socio-Economic Impact Assessments and COVID-19 Recovery
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 3.1 Timely completion of Socio-Economic Impact Assessment of COVD19 Impacts on Samoa 3.2 Timely completion of Rapid Assessment of Vulnerabilities in Rarotonga and Autitaki Cook Islands due to the COVID19

comment.narrative: 3.1 Completed SEIA of COVID19 Impacts on Samoa that is fully costed 3.2 Completed Rapid Assessment of Vulnerabilities in Rarotonga and Aitutaki Cook Islands due to COVID19 3.3 Completed SEIA of COVID19 Impacts on Tokelau that is fully costed

The initial SEIA for Samoa has been completed, but primary household-level data collection is still underway and on track.
In May, UNDP partnered with the Cook Islands Ministry of Internal Affairs and ADB to support the Rapid Assessment for COVID-19 related vulnerability and perceptions on Rarotonga and Aituitaki. Findings from this assessment highlighted the impact of COVID on household welfare and employment, and provided insights to assist in the development of the Government's socio-economic response.
The Pa Enua Rapid assessment on the welfare of vulnerable people is pending.

description.narrative: 1. Number of cases reported and tracked between April and September 2020 2. raising exercises, nationally and in their constituencies; number of MPs supported to create platforms for effective communication with constituents

comment.narrative: 1. Referral Pathway developed with limited implementation 2. 4 out of 111 MPs discuss or mention risk of increased incidents of GBV within the COVID_19 outbreak; 75 out of 111 MPs maintain effective platforms for effective communication with constituents

Activity 1: Operation support to Femili PNG and police officers working on the frontline to expand their scope of work to follow up and monitor the localities with high incidents of crime and GBV cases
Target: At least 60 percent of cases reported are referred to safe houses and are tracked
Activity 2: Support members of parliament to deliver correct and effective messages on GBV prevention within the COVID-19 outbreak
Target: At least 50 percent of MPs deliver correct and effective messages on GBV prevention within the COVID-19 outbreak
Activity 3: Provide platform for citizens to bring issues and needs to the attention of their political representatives and for their representative to respond to concerns
Target: At least 50 percent of MPs are able to provide citizens with platforms to respond to concerns

Activity 1 Target: At least 60 percent of cases reported are referred to safe houses and are tracked
Result: The RPNGC is still yet to establish the information management system. Once establish the percent of clients referred to safe houses can be tracked. However, with the engagement of Femili PNG as the implementing partner in strengthening safe houses FPNG was able to provide assistance to over 432 (Female Adults = 302, Female Child = 27, Male Adults = 16, Male Child = 15 and Child Dependents accompanying Female adults to safe accommodation = 72) Female survivors of FSV and individuals. About 40 percent of the survivors assisted were people living with disabilities (Female Adults = 14 percent, Female Child = 7 percent and Male Adults = 19 percent). Furthermore, food, utilities, hygiene and other necessity support was also provided to 83 percent of Female Adults, 14 percent of Female Child and 3 percent Male Child; including provision of emergency assistance to 94 percent of Female Adults, 4 percent of Female Child and 2 percent of Male Child. A total of 584 World Health Organization posters and 3550 National Department of Health posters on COVID were also distributed between July and October 2020.
Activity 2 Target: At least 50 percent of MPs deliver correct and effective messages on GBV prevention within the COVID-19 outbreak
Result: A parliamentary committee on the coalition against GBV was formed and signed by 20 members of parliament. This is 18 percent of the targeted 50 percent. They have been greatly supported by their spouses with Mrs. Marape leading the mobilzation of the spouses. Mrs. Toroama, the wife of president Toroama is also involved.
Activity 3 Target: At least 50 percent of MPs are able to provide citizens with platforms to respond to concerns Result: This is the same as above and will continue to be monitored over the cause of 2021

description.narrative: The aim is to rapidly enable a cash transfer mechanism for those at risk by covid-19
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 600,000 poor households access to national cash transfer programme during the Covid-19 pandemic

comment.narrative: On-Demand Identification of Poor Households registration

A total of 674,146 households affected by COVID-19 are now able to access cash transfers from the Government. The rapid implementation of this cash transfer programme was facilitated by UNDP’s mobilization of funding from Australia to provide 1,700 tablets and software to the Ministry of Planning along with training for rapid and accurate registration of citizens into Cambodia’s social protection identification system [On Demand Identification of Poor Households (OD-ID Poor)]. This has progressed digitalization of the system and served as the basis to reach the extreme poor and vulnerable. The rapid implementation of the cash transfer program has also been a remarkable success for showing Government capacity at central and subnational levels. It has given rise to a fundamental shift in many parts of Government to a deeper and more positive appreciation of social protection.

description.narrative: In Myanmar, UNDP, as part of the UN Country Team (UNCT), is on the frontline supporting the Government of Myanmar (GoM) to urgently and effectively respond to COVID-19, while safeguarding development progress towards the SDGs and delivering on the pledge to leave no one behind. UNDP is undertaking this initiative as a central component of the UN system-wide response and in support of UNCT’s Country Preparedness and Response Plan (CPRP) that is aligned to and guided by WHO’s Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan, and in lockstep with humanitarian partners under the Global Humanitarian Respon
COVID Rapid Res through Provision of Personal Protective Equipment and improved Radio Communication
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: Frontline health workers are better protected against Covid-19

comment.narrative: Support provincial governments in better management of COVID-19 response

Nepal’s health workers are now better protected against COVID-19 and prepared to manage the outbreak through direct support from the UNDP Nepal CO and Field Offices. In total, over 165,000 surgical and cloth masks have been provided to frontline responders through local governments. A new Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing machine, with the capacity of analysing more than 200 tests per day was installed in Lumbini Provincial Hospital of Province 5. The public awareness of COVID-19, immediate protection measures, and short-term response and recovery efforts has been significantly enhanced. In total, over 3 million people have been reached through radio, public service announcements (PSAs) and social media, in an effort to assist in resolving health, social and economic issues during the crisis. More than 1,500 people also received direct support through call-in radio programmes, with 30 per cent of issues resolved. Some examples included ensuring that immediate relief support reached the most vulnerable groups, connecting farmers with buyers, and providing medical advice to pregnant mothers. With support from UNDP, UNFPA and UN Women, The Association of Community Radio Broadcasters (ACORAB) and its Community Information Network (CIN), hosted the popular radio show ‘Jeevan Rakshya’ to ensure continued connectivity and access to relevant authorities and support services, despite mobility restrictions during the nation-wide lockdown.

description.narrative: Conduct socio-economic and livelihoods impact assessments focusing on vulnerable population
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: Impact assessment report available

comment.narrative: Conduct livelihood impact assessments by Covid-19

In early March, with just a handful of positive cases in Nepal but with strict lockdown measures, UNDP was one of the first organizations to initiate a rapid socio-economic assessment in Nepal to gauge the impact of the crisis particularly on the most vulnerable demographics. UNDP commissioned this rapid assessment which was based on phone surveys of 700 businesses and 400 individuals, and consultations with over 30 private sector organizations and government agencies. The assessment provided the first glimpses into the unfolding disruptions in the economy and the lives of the most vulnerable. The report illustrated the way the crisis was threatening the survival of formal and informal MSMEs and the livelihoods of informal workers, women from lower income households putting at risk the most vulnerable of falling further into poverty through widespread of income and jobs. The rapid assessment recommended three policy takeaways. First, to guard against vulnerabilities including those induced by climate by strengthening social protection, building climate resilient infrastructure and sustaining livelihoods. Second, to orient Nepal’s pattern of public finances to augment human capabilities to safeguard development gains and build economic resilience. And third, to introduce measures to save bankruptcies of firms and foster new sources of job creating growth and self-reliance. These early findings commissioned by UNDP was shared with UNCT agencies, the government and development partners and meaningfully informed the planning of response and recovery initiatives.
In addition, the Rapid Assessment of the Effect of COVID-19 Pandemic on the Economy of Gandaki Province was conducted in UNDP’s support. The findings of the assessment have been utilized by the Province Government in Gandaki to inform its macro-economic forecasting and sectoral impacts.

description.narrative: Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational level

comment.narrative: Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational = 9

Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational = 9
UNDP’s support to the health systems by delivering health related items at the state and regional levels will further strengthen its partnership with the local governments and help to leverage and significantly ramp up not only COVID response efforts but also ongoing programming to reach the presently hard-to-reach and conflict impacted communities through a COVID-19 early recovery programming with potential funding from the Government and other development partners. UNDP has already provided about 28,000 hygiene items (hand sanitizers, soaps, cloth masks etc) and 1260 qty of infra-red thermometers to 26 government offices and development partners. In addition, UNDP is planning to deliver 12 out of 22 types of Health related items which includes about 15,000 pieces of PPE items (goggles, surgical gowns etc in addition to other PPE items) , 8 Ventilators, 20 Oxygen Concentrators, 275 Pulse oximeters, 5 suction machines, 5 portable X-rays machines and 45,000 surgical masks for 9 S/R Governments.
Not Applicable. The output starts in 2020.
Not Applicable. The output starts in 2020.
Not Applicable. The output starts in 2020.
Not Applicable. The output starts in 2020.

description.narrative: COVID-19: Supporting the health response including the procurement and supply of essential health products, strengthening crisis management and response, and addressing critical social and economic impacts.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1.1 Availability of Plan for fast-track health procurement in crisis situations 1.2. % of requested PPE for COVID-19 delivered within 3 months 2.1 Most vulnerable people and criteria for aid are identified. 2.2 Number of beneficiaries from vulnerable populations received social support (packages). 2.3 Number of beneficiaries reached with reliable COVID-19 information and community support.

comment.narrative:
1.1 Preparedness and Response Plan of Turkmenistan To Coronavirus Infection Covid-19.
1.2. National plan for fast-tracking health procurement in crisis situations not available.
2.1 The Government support scheme for the most vulnerable not available.

1.1 Plan for fast-track health procurement in crisis situations: Developed/in progress/not developed 1.2 100% of all requested PPE delivered within 3 months 2.1 Most vulnerable people and criteria for aid are set up: Yes/ In progress/ No 2.2 At least 700 beneficiaries from vulnerable populations received social aid 2.3 At least 10,000 people provided with community support and information

1.1. Turkmenistan’s Comprehensive Action Plan for sanitary protection of the etrap/city territory from the outbreak and spread of especially dangerous and quarantine diseases was updated with UNDP support.
1.2. Eight disinfectant skid sprayers were procured for the sanitary-epidemiological service of Turkmenistan within 3 months
2.1. Rapid scan of vulnerabilities and insecurities of vulnerable groups of the population was conducted by UNDP.
2.2. 13690 food and hygiene parcels and 40500 facemasks were procured and delivered to 7940 people from the most-affected vulnerable groups of the population (low-income families, children with special needs, people with disabilities, single mothers of many children, lone elderly people) that were identified through the rapid scan of vulnerabilities and insecurities of vulnerable groups of the population.
2.3 UNDP provided funds to support the Ministry of Health in printing 5000 information booklets on COVID-19 awareness and prevention measures that were distributed among the most-affected vulnerable groups of the population.

comment.narrative: 37 Palikas 20 of cooperatives, market centres, and palikas 65 returnees and youth 140 extension staff and market operators

• 32 Palikas received relief fund and utilize it • 7 Palika/cooperatives received transportation and market support • 60 returnees migrants from 5 Palikas already selected and 50 returnees already identify their business, received business plan preparation training and prepare their business plan, receiving technical and financial support 20 returnee from 2 Palikas are selected and will received training in early January • 77 Extension Staffs and 24 market/collection centers operators received protective materials
• Provide business plan training to remaining 20 returnees • Continuous technical and materials supports to returnee migrants on their business plan

description.narrative: Los productos y actividades propuestos en este Plan de Iniciación responden tanto a las prioridades del gobierno como a su solicitud de apoyo, y articulan el soporte brindado por sus socios y donantes. Estos se encuentran alineados con la Estrategia Global de PNUD para dar respuesta a la pandemia provocada por COVID-19, el Plan estratégico de acción y preparación de la OMS / OPS, y el plan de respuesta inter agencial de Naciones Unidas, con el fin de potenciar la articulación y la eficacia de acción desde las capacidades del Sistema de Naciones Unidas en su conjunto.

description.narrative: The project seeks to alleviate the impact of COVID-19 on the most vulnerable demographics by offering opportunities to earn incomes through a combination of business activities, particularly via Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs), and social protection measures aimed at maintaining basic subsistence and food security.

description.narrative: • Mapping of access to connectivity and IT resources within Ministries. • # of gender-responsive business continuity plans developed through participatory process (disaggregated by Ministry) • # of Private-public partnerships formulated to support enhanced tech capacities of government (disaggregated by ministry and type of support). • # of units of hardware sold at subsidized rates. • At least 2 softwares are utilized for video conferencing and group meetings online (such as skype for business and zoom) • # of Focal Point Networks established • Ratio of women: men representatives in Focal Point Networks • # of women civil servants interviewed about perceptions of working-from-home modality • # grants to CSOs responding to GBV in communities • # of survivors accessing shelters (disagregatted by age, geographical area, citizen status and gender)

comment.narrative: the available data base of municipalities at the Property tax project

• Mapping on Government access to IT resources and internet reach • Response plan to inform decision taking • Private-Public partnerships aiming at to reduce costs or subsidize communications (internet and phone) for a six-month period and to supply subsidized or reduce cost hardware to identified vulnerable groups • Remote work plans and technology implementations guidelines aim to ensure smooth operations and healthcare safety of civil servants • Interim intranet system designed to allow enable Government’s business continuity across the 100 municipalities of Jordan. • Focal points and core staff are equipped with hardware and software to virtually meet and take decisions • Modalities are modified to accommodate needs of women working from home. • Government partners engage in active discussions on subject of social repercussions of COVID-19 Shelters and hotlines remain operational during the lockdown

description.narrative: Number of people tested through kits

comment.narrative: Strengthening Libya’s health system response by equipping Libyan testing, treatment and isolation centers to ensure access and response to the COVID-19 epidemic and supporting innovative digital solutions to healthcare gaps. Assessing the socio-economic impact of the crisis and supporting a recovery strategy

UNDP responded to COVID by enhancing national and local health sector capacities. UNDP Libya recruited and placed three health experts within the Ministry of Health (MoH) and Presidential Council to support the coordination of COVID response among UN agencies, NGOs, MoH and other related line Ministries. UNDP is developing an innovative application to set up a Telemedicine system for remote diagnosis of vulnerable populations by doctors. 15,000 test kits and 5 GenX machines procured and distributed to centres
Inclusive and integrated crisis management in enhanced through a whole-of-society response to COVID-19 Gender sensitive post-COVID recovery strategy
